stem: Click to highlight the findings that are most likely associated with the client's current neurologic event.
passage: A [72-year-old female] is evaluated in the Emergency Department for [sudden onset of left-sided weakness] and [slurred speech] that began 45 minutes ago. The nurse notes [facial drooping on the left side] and a [BP of 192/104 mmHg]. The client appears [anxious but cooperative].
correctSpans: facial drooping on the left side

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
S: 72/F brought by EMS for acute neurologic changes.
B: History of hypertension and atrial fibrillation. Non-compliant with apixaban.
A: Sudden onset left-sided hemiparesis. GCS 14 (E4, V4, M6).
R: Initiate stroke protocol and prepare for CT head.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: Time: 14:00 | BP: 192/104 | HR: 98 (irregular) | RR: 18 | SpO2: 95% on RA

rationale.correct: Sudden onset focal neurologic deficits (weakness, speech, facial droop) are hallmark signs of acute ischemic stroke.

answerBreakdown.label: sudden onset of left-sided weakness
answerBreakdown.content: Classical presentation of stroke affecting the right hemisphere.

clinicalPearls: Time is Brain: Rapid recognition is key for tPA eligibility.

questionTrap.trap: Highlighting hypertension as a sign of stroke.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Hypertension is a risk factor or compensation, not always a clinical sign of the stroke itself in the same way focal deficits are.

mnemonic.title: B.E. F.A.S.T.
mnemonic.expansion: Balance, Eyes, Face, Arms, Speech, Time
